content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is the function in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    audi_a4 = df_cars[ (df_cars.manufacturer .== "audi") .& ((df_cars.model .== "a4") .| (df_cars.model .== "a4 quattro")), :]
    insertcols(audi_a4, :audi_a4_type => true)
end
```
This function first filters out the rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Then it adds a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values set to `true`.

Note: Please ensure that the DataFrame `df_cars` has columns named `manufacturer`, `model` for this function to work correctly. Also make sure you have loaded the necessary packages using the `using` statement at the beginning of your script.
